III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Intervention standards and prohibitions
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
Description policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A staff member “Peter” placed youth in a chokehold while the
youth was placed at the facility in October 2023.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant was interviewed via telephone on 7/18/2024.
Complainant reported Youth A has significant mental health
concerns and has been hospitalized several times as a result of
his mental health. Complainant reported it was unclear if “Peter”
was a real person or an imaginary person as Youth A initially said
“Peter” was a staff and then “Peter” was a youth from the hospital.
Complainant asked Youth A if other people could see or hear
“Peter” and Youth A did not respond and stared with a blank look
on his face.
Youth A was interviewed via telephone on 7/10/2024 as Youth
A is no longer at the facility. Youth A reported he was placed at
Eagle Village for one day however was unable to recall when.
Youth A reported it was “not good” at the facility however was
unable to provide any reasons or examples of what was not good.
Youth A did not recall any staff from the facility. Youth A reported
he was restrained at the facility however did not know any of the
staff who restrained him. Youth A reported he knows a man by
the name “Peter” and he saw “Peter” at Eagle Village and once at
his current placement. Youth A described “Peter” as a Caucasian
male, six foot tall, in his 30’s, with gray hair. Youth A reported
“Peter” always wears the same cloths, a white shirt and green
pants. Youth A reported “Peter” just shows up when he is mad.
Youth A reported “Peter” has told Youth A to kill himself and while
Youth A was at the facility he reported “Peter choked me and tried
to kill me”. Youth A reported other people cannot see or hear
“Peter”.
2

Foster Care Worker was interviewed via telephone on
7/10/2024. Foster Care Worker reported Youth A was placed at
Eagle Village Leppien house for less than twelve hours due to
significant mental health concerns which resulted in
hospitalization. Foster Care Worker reported Youth A has a
significant mental health history including hallucinations which
Youth A was experiencing during the twelve hours he was placed
at the facility. Youth A has never reported any allegations to
Foster Care Worker about being placed in a choke hold by a staff
named “Peter”. Foster Care Worker reported Youth A has a
history of making allegations after leaving facilities and it has been
difficult to determine if the allegations are true or hallucinations.
Case Coordinator was interviewed via telephone on
7/11/2024. Case Coordinator reported Youth A initially reported
“Peter” was a staff at Eagle Village and then changed his story to
“Peter” was a youth at the hospital where he was after Eagle
Village. Youth A reported to Case Coordinator “Peter” was not
nice to him at the hospital and hurt him. Case Coordinator
reported Youth A is struggling with his mental health and recently
reported he is seeing “Peter”. Case Coordinator reported Youth A
informed Youth A’s Psychologist about “Peter” this past Monday.
Case Coordinator reported at this time Youth A is not showing any
textbook signs of hallucinations.
Administrator 1 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
7/15/2024. Administrator 1 reported she briefly recalled Youth A
and reported he was not at the facility long as he was hospitalized
due to his mental health. Administrator 1 reported the facility has
not had a staff named “Peter” in several years. Administrator 1
denied any current or past staff meeting the description of
Caucasian male, six feet tall, in their 30’s, with gray hair and
wearing green pants and a white shirt. Administrator 1 reported
white shirts are against the facility dress code for staff.
Administrator 2 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
7/15/2024. Administrator 2 briefly recalled Youth A. Administrator
2 reported Youth A was taken to the local hospital within the first
day of being at the facility due to mental health needs.
Administrator 2 reported the facility has not had any staff by the
name “Peter” since 2020. Administrator 2 denied any current or
past staff meeting the description of Caucasian male, six feet tall,
in their 30’s, with gray hair and wearing green pants and a white
shirt. Administrator 2 reported she does not know of any former
employees that would have been employed at Eagle Village when
Youth A was at the facility that now work at Children’s Village.
3

Administrator 3 was interviewed face-to-face at the facility on
7/15/2024. Administrator 3 reported Youth A was at the facility for
a short time as he was taken to the hospital for evaluation due to
extreme dysregulation and inability to calm down. Youth A met
criteria for hospitalization and was hospitalized for his mental
health needs. Administrator 3 denied the facility having any staff
by the name “Peter” in the timeframe Youth A was at the facility.
Administrator 3 denied any current or past staff meeting the
description of Caucasian male, six feet tall, in their 30’s, with gray
hair and wearing green pants and a white shirt.
Clinical Case Manager was interviewed face-to-face at the
facility on 7/15/2024. Clinical Case Manager reported Youth A
was placed at the facility on 10/2/2023 and had difficulty regulating
at the facility. Youth A was taken to Reed City Hospital on
10/3/2023 due to mental health concerns and was hospitalized.
Youth A remained in Reed City Hospital from 10/3/2023 until
10/7/2023 when he was placed at Helen Devos. Clinical Case
Manager reported Youth A was staffed one-to-one while at the
hospital from 10/3/2023-10/7/2023. Clinical Case Manager
reported she worked several of the one-to-one staffing with Youth
A at the hospital. Clinical Case Manager reported Youth A never
made any statements to her about any “Peter” or “Peter choking
him”. Clinical Case Manager was able to pull the one-to-one
staffing for Youth A while he was at the hospital and reported no
male staff worked any of the one-to-ones with Youth A.
Documents Reviewed:
• Michigan Department of Health & Human Service Plan
dated 12/7/2023 for Youth A: Social work contact dated
10/3/2023 states Youth A is currently in Reed City ER and
was assessed by Community Mental Health and it was
determined hospitalization was needed due to Youth A
being suicidal and experiencing psychosis as Youth A is
exhibiting concerning behaviors including head banging to
the point of self-injury, assaultive behaviors, hallucinations,
and suicidal statements.
Youth A is diagnosed with Disruptive Mood Dysregulation
Disorder, ADHD, Borderline Intellectual Functioning, Child
Psychological Abuse, Bipolar, Anxiety, and Depression.
Youth A is on psychotropic medications to address his
diagnosis. Youth A was placed at Eagle Village Hainley
house 10/2/2023-10/7/2023.
4

• Michigan Department of Health & Human Services Incident
Report 164450211, 164450214, 164440212, 164450213,
164460211, and 164460210 dated 10/2/2023: Youth A was
restrained due to self-harming behaviors. There were no
male staff named Peter listed on the incident report.
• Eagle Village Search of Employee information showing the
facility does not have any staff by the name Peter.
• Eagle Village staffing one-on-one for Youth A while
hospitalized showed no males worked with Youth A from
10/3/2023-10/7/2023 except Administrator 3 who worked
with Youth A on 10/3/2023 from 3:30pm-5:30pm with
another female staff.
• Eagle Village Residential Services Standard Operating
Procedures Therapeutic Holds: The only approved
therapeutic hold techniques are the methods and techniques
taught in the required Aegis course and should only be used
when a resident is a serious threat of safety or violence to
self or others and/or after all verbal de-escalation and
behavior support techniques have been exhausted.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance based on interviews as Youth A
reported he saw “Peter” at Eagle Village and Children’s Village
and “Peter” comes when Youth A is mad. Youth A reported other
people cannot see or hear “Peter”. Verification was made at
Eagle Village and per interviews and review of documentation,
there was not a “Peter” employed at the facility in October 2023
nor was there anyone meeting the description Youth A provided.
Youth A was at Eagle Village for one night and then placed in
inpatient hospital care due to mental health needs including
hallucination.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
